content: 1:1 Ahasuerus. reigned … over 127 provinces. India to Ethiopia. Ahasuerus. See Introduction: Background and Setting . reigned … over 127 provinces. The kingdom comprised 20 regions ( 3:12 ; 8:9 ; 9:3 ) which were further divided into provinces ruled over by governors ( 3:12 ). India to Ethiopia. Ethiopia, not Asia Minor, is mentioned as representing the western edge of the kingdom to avoid any remembrance of the king’s previous defeat by the Greeks ca. 481–479 BC (cf. 8:9 ). This description also avoided any confusion with the Ahasuerus of Da 9:1 .

1:2 the citadel in Susa. the citadel in Susa. Susa, the winter residence, was one of 4 capital cities; the other 3 included Babylon, Ecbatana ( Ezr 6:2 ), and Persepolis. The citadel refers to the fortified palace complex built above the city for protection.

1:3 the third year. Persia and Media. the third year. Ca. 483 BC. This probably included the planning phase for Ahasuerus’ later campaign against Greece in which the king suffered a humiliating defeat (ca. 481–479 BC). Persia and Media. Cyrus the Persian inherited Media and thus the name Media became just as prominent as Persia (ca. 550 BC).

1:9 Queen Vashti. Queen Vashti. Greek literature records her name as Amestris. She gave birth (ca. 483 BC) to Ahasuerus’ third son, Artaxerxes, who later succeeded his father Ahasuerus on the throne ( Ezr 7:1 ).

1:12 Vashti refused. Vashti refused. Her reason is not recorded, although suggestions have included that 1) her appearance would have involved lewd behavior before drunken men, or 2) that she was still pregnant with Artaxerxes.
1:14 the seven princes. the seven princes. These highest ranking officials (cf. Ezr 7:14 ) were perhaps equivalent to the magi of Da 1:20 .
1:19 cannot be repealed. cannot be repealed. The irrevocable nature of Persian law (cf. Da 6:8 , 12 , 15 ) played an important role in how the rest of Esther concluded (cf. 8:8 ).
1:22 letters. letters. The efficient Persian communication network (a rapid relay by horses) played an important role in speedily publishing kingdom edicts (cf. 3:12–14 ; 8:9–10 , 14 ; 9:20 , 30 ).

2:1 After these things. he remembered Vashti. After these things. Most likely during the latter portion of the king’s ill-fated war with Greece (ca. 481–479 BC). he remembered Vashti. The king was legally unable to restore Vashti (cf. 1:19–22 ), so the counselors proposed a new plan with promise.

2:5 Mordecai. Kish. Mordecai. See Introduction: Historical and Theological Themes . He was among the fourth generation of deported Jews. Kish. Mordecai’s great grandfather who actually experienced the Babylonian deportation. After Babylon fell to Medo-Persia (ca. 539 BC), Jews were moved to other parts of the new kingdom. Kish represents a Benjamite family name that could be traced back (ca. 1100 BC) to Saul’s father ( 1Sa 9:1 ).

2:6 Jeconiah. Jeconiah. Former king of Judah (also known as Jehoiachin and Coniah) who was deported ca. 597 BC (cf. 2Ki 24:14–15 ; 2Chr 36:9–10 ). Due to his disobedience, Yahweh removed his descendants from the line of David to Christ ( Jer 22:24–30 ). The family of Mordecai and Esther were part of the good figs in Jer 24:1–7 .
2:7 Esther. Esther. See Introduction: Title .
2:8 Esther was taken. Esther was taken. It is impossible to tell if Esther went voluntarily or against her will.
2:9 was good in his eyes. was good in his eyes. That she pleased Hegai points to God’s providential control.
2:10 not tell about . not tell anyone about them . Possibly because of the hostile letter mentioned in Ezr 4:6 or the anti-Semitic sentiments of Haman and other like-minded people.
2:14 the second harem. the second harem. The place of concubines.
2:15 advanced in favor. advanced in favor. According to Yahweh’s providential plan.
2:16 Tebeth. the seventh year. Tebeth. The tenth month corresponding to Dec./Jan. the seventh year. Ca. 479–478 BC. Four years had elapsed since Vashti’s fall from favor.
2:18 a remission of taxes. a remission of taxes. The Hebrew phrase may also indicate release from military service.
2:19 the second time. the second time. Perhaps the king intended to add the second best to his concubine collection.

2:21 the king’s gate. became furious. the king’s gate. Indicates the strong possibility that Mordecai held a position of prominence (cf. 3:2 ; Da 2:49 ). became furious. Perhaps in revenge over the loss of Vashti.

2:23 hanged on a gallows. book of the chronicles. hanged on a gallows. The Persian execution consisted of being impaled (cf. Ezr 6:11 ). It is likely that they were the inventors of crucifixion. book of the chronicles. The king would 5 years later (Ahasuerus’ 12th year) read these Persian records as the turning point in Esther ( 6:1–2 ).

3:1 After these things. Haman … the Agagite. After these things. Sometime between the seventh ( 2:16 ) and twelfth year ( 3:7 ) of the king’s reign. Haman … the Agagite. See Introduction: Historical and Theological Themes .

3:2 would not bow down. would not bow down. There is a question as to whether Esther and Mordecai were inclined to obey the Mosaic law. This refusal may be more likely grounded in the family feud between the Benjamites and the Agagites (see Introduction: Historical and Theological Themes ) than Mordecai’s allegiance to the second commandment ( Ex 20:4–6 ).

3:4 he was a Jew. he was a Jew. It seems evident from Haman’s fury and attempted genocide that there were strong anti-Semitic attitudes in Susa, which seems to explain Mordecai’s reluctance to reveal his true ethnic background.

3:6 the people of Mordecai. the people of Mordecai. Haman was being satanically used to target the entire Jewish race in an unsuccessful attempt to change the course of redemptive history and God’s plans for Israel.

3:7 Nisan. twelfth year. Pur … lot. Adar. Nisan. The time period Mar./Apr. Ironically, the Jews should have been celebrating the Passover to remind them of a former deliverance. twelfth year. Ca. 474 BC. Pur … lot. A lot would be like modern dice which were cast to determine future decisions (cf. the Hebrew lot, 1Chr 26:14 ; Ne 10:34 ; Jon 1:7 ). Proverbs 16:33 states that God providentially controlled the outcome of the lot. Adar. Feb./Mar. There would have been an 11 month interval between Haman’s decree and its expected fulfillment.
3:8 a certain people. a certain people. Haman never divulged their identity.

3:9 10,000 talents. 10,000 talents. The exact dollar amount is uncertain, but reportedly it would have weighed 375 tons and equaled almost 70 percent of the king’s annual revenue. Since this sum would have been derived from the plunder of the Jews, it indicates that they had grown prosperous.
3:10–11 The king would have easily been eager to eliminate any rebellion against his authority (cf. 3:8 ), although he did not seem to be interested in the money.
3:12 sealed … king’s signet ring. sealed … king’s signet ring. This would be equivalent to the king’s signature. The date has been calculated by historians to be Apr. 7, 474 BC.

3:13 to destroy. to destroy. An ambitious plot to annihilate the Jews in just one day. Historians have calculated the date to be Mar. 7, 473 BC. The king had unwittingly approved this provision which would kill his own queen.
3:14 as law. as law. It would be irrevocable (cf. 1:19 ; 8:5–8 ).
3:15 in confusion. in confusion. No specific reason is stated. Most likely even this pagan population was puzzled at the extreme and deadly racism of the king and Haman.

4:1 sackcloth and ashes. sackcloth and ashes. An outward sign of inward distress and humiliation (cf. Jer 6:26 ; Da 9:3 ; Mt 11:21 ). Mordecai realized that he had prompted this genocidal retaliation by Haman.
4:4 she sent garments. she sent garments. Mordecai could then enter the king’s gate (cf. 4:2 ) and talk with Esther directly (cf. Ne 2:2 ).
4:5 Hathach. Hathach. A trusted eunuch who knew of Esther’s Jewish background.
4:7–8 That Mordecai possessed this specific knowledge and a copy of the edict further evidences his prominent position in Persia.

4:11 golden scepter. these thirty days. golden scepter. In order to protect the king’s life from would-be assassins, this practice prevailed. Seemingly, the king would extend the scepter (a sign of kingly authority) only to those whom he knew and from whom he welcomed a visit (cf. 5:2 ; 8:4 ). these thirty days. Perhaps Esther feared she had lost favor with the king since he had not summoned her recently.

4:14 relief and deliverance. you … will perish. such a time as this. relief and deliverance. Mordecai exhibited a healthy faith in God’s sovereign power to preserve His people. He may have remembered Yahweh’s promise to Abraham (cf. Ge 12:3 ; 17:1–8 ). you … will perish. Mordecai indicated that Esther would not escape the sentence or be overlooked because of her prominence (cf. 4:13 ). such a time as this. Mordecai indirectly appealed to God’s providential timing.

4:16 fast. perish. fast. The text does not mention prayer being included such as was Daniel’s practice ( Da 9:3 ), though it surely was. perish. Esther’s heroic willingness to die for the sake of her fellow Jews is commendable.
5:2 she advanced in favor. she advanced in favor. This actually means that Esther first found favor with the God of Israel (cf. Pr 21:1 ).
5:3 what is your request? what is your request? Esther deferred her real wish until 7:2–3 .
5:4 the feast. the feast. The first of two (cf. 5:4–8 ; 6:14—7:1 ) that Esther prepared. God would providentially intervene between the two ( 6:1–2 ).
5:11 the number of his sons. the number of his sons. At least 10 sons were fathered by Haman (cf. 9:13 ), who personified sinful pride (cf. Pr 16:18 ; 1Co 10:12 ; Ga 6:3 ).
5:13 is worth nothing to me. is worth nothing to me. Haman expressed raging fixation on killing Mordecai.

5:14 gallows. fifty cubits. gallows. A stake on which a human would be impaled to death and/or displayed after death (cf. 2:23 ). fifty cubits. Approximately 75 ft. or almost 8 stories high. Perhaps the gallows involved displaying a shorter stake atop a building or wall to attain this height.

6:1 the book. the book. Five years (cf. 2:16 with 3:7 ) had intervened since Mordecai’s loyal, but as yet unrewarded, act (cf. 2:23 ). At exactly the proper moment, God providentially intervened so that the king suffered insomnia, called for the book of records, read of Mordecai’s unrewarded deeds 5 years past, and then desired to reward him (cf. Da 6:18 ).
6:4 Who is in the court? Who is in the court? The drama intensified as Haman arrived at just the wrong time and for just the wrong reason.
6:6–7 Haman ironically defined the honor to be given to Mordecai at Haman’s expense. To his potential wealth from the Jewish plunder, he thought public acclaim would be added.

6:8 royal robe … royal crown. royal robe … royal crown. An honor which involved being treated as though the recipient were the king himself (cf. 8:15 ). This is reminiscent of Joseph in Egypt ( Ge 41:39–45 ). History affirms that horses were adorned with the royal crown.
6:9 the city square. the city square. Whereas Mordecai had been there the day before in sackcloth and ashes ( 4:1 , 6 ), he arrived with royal honor.
6:10 Mordecai the Jew. Mordecai the Jew. Cf. 8:7 ; 9:29 , 31 ; 10:3 . Why the king did not remember Haman’s edict against the Jews remains unknown.

6:12 mourning. head covered. mourning. Deservedly, Haman has inherited Mordecai’s distress (cf. 4:1–2 ). What a difference a day makes! His imagined honors had quickly turned to unimaginable humiliation. his head covered. An extreme sign of shame (cf. 2Sa 15:30 ; Jer 14:3–4 ).

6:13 you have begun to fall. you have begun to fall. Neither divine prophecy ( Ex 17:14 ) nor biblical history ( 1Sa 15:8–9 ) stood in Haman’s favor. Haman’s entourage seemed to have some knowledge of this biblical history.
6:14 Haman to the feast. Haman to the feast. Like a lamb led to slaughter, Haman was escorted off to his just due.

7:2 second day. what is your request? second day. The first-day reference point included the first feast. This refers to the second banquet on the second day (cf. 5:8 ). what is your request? This was the third time that the king inquired (cf. 5:3 , 6 ).
7:3 my people. my people. This plea paralleled God’s message through Moses to Pharaoh, “Let My people go,” almost 1,000 years earlier ( Ex 7:16 ).

7:4 sold. destroyed … killed … caused to perish. sold. Refers back to Haman’s bribe (cf. 3:9 ; 4:7 ). destroyed … killed … caused to perish. Esther recounted the exact language of Haman’s decree (cf. 3:13 ).
7:6 this evil Haman. this evil Haman. Similar to Nathan’s famous accusation against King David, “You are the man” ( 2Sa 12:7 ). Haman’s honor had quickly turned to humiliation, and then to horror.
7:8 assault the queen. assault the queen. Blinded by anger, Ahasuerus interpreted Haman’s plea to be an act of violence against Esther rather than a plea for mercy.

7:9 Harbonah. Behold. Mordecai who spoke good. Harbonah. Cf. 1:10 . Behold. Because the place prepared by Haman for Mordecai’s execution towered above the city, it became the obvious spot for Haman’s death. Mordecai who spoke good. Haman heard the third capital offense charged against him. One, he manipulated the king in planning to kill the queen’s people. Two, he was perceived to accost the queen. Three, he planned to execute a man whom the king had just greatly honored for extreme loyalty to the kingdom.
7:10 they hanged Haman. they hanged Haman. The ultimate expression of justice (cf. Ps 9:15–16 ).

8:1 the house of Haman. the house of Haman. Property of a traitor by Persian custom returned to the king. In this case, he gave it to his queen, Esther, who put Mordecai over it ( 8:2 ). The outcome for Haman’s wife Zeresh and his wise men is unknown ( 5:14 ; 6:12–13 ). Haman’s 10 sons later died ( 9:7–10 ).
8:5 to turn back. to turn back. This proved to be impossible in light of the inflexible nature of the king’s edicts ( 1:19 ). However, a counter-decree was possible (cf. 8:8 , 11–12 ).

8:9 Sivan. Sivan. Refers to the period May/June. It had been two months and 10 days since Haman’s decree (cf. 3:12 ); 8 months and 20 days remained until both decrees became simultaneously effective (cf. 3:13 ).
8:11 the king gave. the king gave. Just as the king had permitted Haman, so he allowed the Jews to defend themselves and to plunder their spoil (cf. 9:10 , 15–16 ).
8:15 Mordecai went out. Mordecai went out. This second reward exceeded the first (cf. 6:6–9 ). Blue and white were the royal colors of the Persian Empire.

8:17 many … peoples … Jews. many … peoples … Jews. The population realized that the God of the Jews greatly exceeded anything that the pantheon of Persian deities could offer (cf. Ex 15:14–16 ; Ps 105:38 ; Ac 5:11 ), especially in contrast to their recent defeat by the Greeks.

9:1 twelfth month. twelfth month. During the period Feb.–Mar. Here is a powerful statement with regard to God’s providential preservation of the Jewish race in harmony with God’s unconditional promise to Abraham ( Ge 17:1–8 ). This providential deliverance stands in contrast to God’s miraculous deliverance of the Jews from Egypt; yet in both cases the same end had been accomplished by the supernatural power of God.

9:3 the dread of Mordecai. the dread of Mordecai. Pragmatically, the nation had a change of heart toward the Jews, knowing that the king, the queen, and Mordecai were the ranking royal officials of the land. To be pro-Jewish would put one in favor with the king and his court and put one on the side of God, the ultimate King (cf. Rev 19:16 ).
9:6–7 Five hundred men died in Susa.

9:10 did not send forth their hand. did not send forth their hand. Unlike Saul, who did take the plunder (cf. 1Sa 15:3 with 15:9 ), the Jews focused only on the mission at hand, i.e., to preserve the Jewish race (cf. vv. 15–16 ), even though the king’s edict permitted this ( 8:11 ).

9:12 further request? further request? Even this pagan king served the cause of utterly blotting out the Amalekites in accord with God’s original decree ( Ex 17:14 ) by allowing for a second day of killing in Susa to eliminate all Jewish enemies.
9:13 be hanged. be hanged. I.e., be publicly displayed.
9:15–16 Over 1,500 years earlier God had promised to curse those who curse Abraham’s descendants ( Ge 12:3 ).
9:16 kill. kill. Outside of Susa, only one day of killing occurred in which 75,000 enemies died.
9:18–19 This section recounted why Purim would be celebrated for two days rather than one.
9:20–25 A brief summary of God’s providential intervention on behalf of the Jews.
9:26 Purim. Purim. The first and last biblically revealed, non-Mosaic festival with perpetual significance.
9:29 second letter. second letter. An additional letter (cf. v. 20 for the first letter), which added “fasting” and “lamentations” to the prescribed activity of Purim.
9:32 written in the book. written in the book. This could be the chronicle referred to in 10:2 , or another archival type document. It certainly does not hint that Esther wrote this canonical book.
10:1–3 Apparently a postscript.

10:3 Mordecai … was second. spoke for the peace. Mordecai … was second. Mordecai joined the top echelon of Jewish international statesmen like Joseph, who ranked second in the Egyptian dynasty ( Ge 41:37–45 ), and Daniel, who succeeded in both the Babylonian ( Da 2:46–49 ; 5:29 ) and Medo-Persian Empires ( Da 6:28 ). spoke for the peace. Less than 10 years later (ca. 465 BC), Ahasuerus was assassinated. There are no further details concerning Esther and Mordecai. What Mordecai did for less than a decade on behalf of Israel, Jesus Christ will do for all eternity as the Prince of Peace ( Is 9:6–7 ; Zec 9:9–10 ).
